title: Valid Mountain Array
content:
Given an array of integers arr, return true if and only if it is a valid mountain array.

Recall that arr is a mountain array if and only if:

  • arr.length >= 3
  • There exists some i with 0 < i < arr.length - 1 such that:
    • arr[0] < arr[1] < ... < arr[i - 1] < arr[i]
    • arr[i] > arr[i + 1] > ... > arr[arr.length - 1]

 

Example 1:

Input: arr = [2,1]
Output: false

Example 2:

Input: arr = [3,5,5]
Output: false

Example 3:

Input: arr = [0,3,2,1]
Output: true

 

Constraints:

  • 1 <= arr.length <= 104
  • 0 <= arr[i] <= 104

discussion_posts.name: Vidhaan_J
discussion_posts.content: Why is the acceptance rate so low? Just find the max element, get the elements behind it and in front of it, and see if the behind elements are strictly increasing, and if the front elements are strictly decreasing. And also add edge case `if arr.index(max(arr))==0 or arr.index(max(arr))==len(arr)-1 or len(arr)<3:\n            return False`

discussion_posts.name: tripper
discussion_posts.content:
This question is categorise as an easy, but as a novice, I struggled to come up with a solution without the help of the editorial.

My intuition was to find the peak index and from there look for monotonically increasing and decreasing `arr` and keeping the edge cases behind I started assigning a `bool increase` and `bool decrease` values to keep track of the `arr` increasing and decreasing order. And returning `increase` and `decrease` if they are `True`.

Here is my code [link](https://leetcode.com/problems/valid-mountain-array/submissions/936234683/)

discussion_posts.name: saketuchil
discussion_posts.content:
1. climb up while arr[i] < arr[i+1].
2. Peak can’t be first or last.
3. Walk down while arr[i] > arr[i+1].
4. valid if you end at last index.
This can be solved using only 1 pointer, no need for 2 pointers.
